solution.text:
\( \Rightarrow \) Upon reducing the fractions to their simplest form, we learn:
Katherine has solved \( \frac {4}{11}\) of the puzzle,
Abhay has solved \( \frac {1}{3}\) of the puzzle,
Nikhil has solved \( \frac {5}{14}\) of the puzzle.
To know who has solved the most, we will find the LCM of the denominators of the 3 fractions, i.e. 11, 3, 14.
Their LCM is 462.
We now write the 3 fractions in such a way that they all have the same denominator , i.e. 462 (hence making comparison easy)
Katherine has solved \( \frac {168}{462}\) of the puzzle,
Abhay has solved \( \frac {154}{462}\) of the puzzle,
Nikhil has solved \( \frac {165}{462}\) of the puzzle.
\( \Rightarrow \) Hence, Katherine has solved most of the puzzle.

content.text: Three students were given the same puzzle. Katherine solved \( \frac {_{{4*k}}_}{_{{11*k}}_}\) of the puzzle, Abhay solved \( \frac {_{{3*j}}_}{_{{9*j}}_}\) of the puzzle and Nikhil solved \( \frac {_{{5*l}}_}{_{{14*l}}_}\) of the puzzle. Who solved the most?
